>>4434957
Basically we found out that a bunch of different plants from different places with similar conditions evolved into similar plants. So two unrelated plants adapted to living in dry areas by reducing leaves and turning them into needles, storing water in the stem and using the engorged stem for photosynthesis instead. Kinda like how the tasmanian tiger is closer to a koala than a dog despite looking more like a dog than a koala.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

Also this is important because it helps understand how to do stuff like grafting and making hybrids. You can graft a tomato to a potato but can't graft a tomato to a persimmon just because both produce red round fruits.

If you want to identify local plants just use an app like iNaturalist or a local field guide. Most cultivated garden plants are only in a handful of families anyway: Fabaceae (beans, peas), Brassicaceae (cabbage, kale, broccoli), Solanaceae (tomatoes, potatoes, eggplants) Rosaceae (roses, apples, pears, cherries), Lamiaceae (mints, basils), and Asteraceae (sunflowers, artichokes). The best beginner's guide is pic related. Sharpen your coloring pencils. Plant Systematics is for bookworm autists. The lesson here is the biggest most impressive looking book isn't the best to get you started. You just end up wading through information you aren't ready to process.

Nice pond. Whats the upkeep like for one of those?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438172
Upkeep is pretty easy if you are smart about the set up. All the pics you see are the same 300 gallon rubbermaid stock tank wrapped with a wooden frame for aesthetics. I'm using pool filter sand as substrate over the rocks now because the sand doesn't trap poop, is much easier for plants to root into, and allows me stock snails and freshwater clams. The circular shape also allows you to have a nice circular flow pattern of water where there isn't any dead spots for shit to collect in. Filtration wise all my water is going down a overflow so the surface is skimmed of dust and leaves. Upkeep routine is once a week I will open the filter and hose down these 12"x12" foam pads and every other week change 50% of the water. During warmer weather when plants grow I will actually have to water change less or else the plants stop growing completely and die off a little. Water changes are super easy since its outdoors and I can drain into my backyard and rapidly refill with the hose. The most demanding part of the pond is just feeding, the fuckers need so much food its unreal. Second most upkeep intensive thing is green string/hair algae, if you don't have enough plants that stuff grows in unbelievables amount, like literally ripping out handfuls every other day.

10/10 recommend anon, seeing your goldfish friends bask in the sunlight and have such large swimming space is really something else

>>4359128
Snowy owls are one of the few animals that unironically ignite my moé instincts. Not only do they look like adorable little angels, they also have the personalities of ones as well. Chick-on-chick infanticide is relatively rare in this species, and on top of that the siblings are known to share their given meals with each other. All the more impressive taking into consideration that they live in an environment that is only slightly more forgiving than the polar ice caps, or planet Hoth.

The species are sexually dimorphic to better suit their familial roles. The male is nearly solid white to blend into the tundra helping him to hide, but that also aids him in hunting lemmings. While the female is a speckled guardian who broods on a nest above permafrost, usually while tenderly pruning her offspring. However, like all parents the will fight beak and claw if any intruder ventures too close, from arctic foxes to polar bears, to the typical human.

If the don't melt your heart, I don't know what will.

Although this image looks like amateur clickbait, prehistoric Crete was a topsy-turvy place featuring elephants and owls the size of goats. The said owls were flightless, long-legged stalkers that pounce on unsuspecting prey, and even in (relatively) modern times Crete was known for lacking in any major carnivores. There was even a myth saying Hercules went on a mass exterminating crusade on the island to honor his literal god father Zeus.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4372256
That is an excellent question for multiple reasons:

1. It will be a fun project to reconstruct the vocal cords of this animal, there was even a YouTube video speculating on how T.Rex most likely sounded like a double bass, due to modern birds (of the large variety) using closed mouth vocals to communicate over a large distance, similar to elephants.

2. But on a more opinionated note. I find it disappointing that there was no grand designs towards this animal, and it reminds me of the enthusiastically, cheesy early iguanodon interpretations. It's better to imagine the creature as a 19th century Godzilla while being based on a single jawbone, rather than a lackluster paragraph on Wikipedia. Imagination is important to tell stories and to fill in the intellectual gaps, (as long as there is systematic evidence).

Crete is an underrated paleo landscape were big was small and vise versa, and it's eerie to think that the ancient Greeks noted the lack of hostile fauna of the island, and they all seemed to have disappeared like the Minoans.

He wont follow anyone around except me cause Ive given him the most pets/praise/treats. You have a puppy so it will require patience since everything distracts him and he wants to follow everything. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4437815
Work on teaching him wait/stay more. Not just when youre leaving but as a general game teach him that waiting and staying still and gentle for you means he gets praise/reward.

Also maybe make less of an event out of you leaving. Dont say goodbye just be gone. Dont gather people to stop him, maybe have him on a leash and one person calmly holds him away while you make a quick calm exit. When you come back you might bring him a treat. Eventually he associates you disappearing with you reappearing with treats. Right now he associates you leaving with him having to be held down and away and theres no reward for it all only stress.

My dog used to be similar but I was making the mistake of feeling guilty and making a big deal of making sure everything was just right for him before I left. Reading tips on dogs I learned thats the worst thing you can do is have a longer drawn out ritual for leaving your dog alone. Much better once I started making my exits quick and dramaless as well as working on his Wait command.

Trying my luck here: my dog fell from 10ft and dislocated his metacarpal bone (pic rel)
First vet just put a splint, then went to another one who said he may need arthrodesis surgery aka permanent joint fusion. Sounds a bit extreme to me

Does anyone know anything about that? Is that surgery the only option?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438428
go see another vet. ideally some bigger vet clinic that is maybe even part of a vet school and has a good orthopedic department. joint fusion is rarely needed. it's mostly a thing for dogs that get run over and have their femur/hip crushed. they then chop the ball of the femur off which creates a net of collagen scar tissue called a pseudo joint in it's place that stabilizes the whole thing. the dogs get to walk again after often. it's not great but it's better than putting them down or a wheelchair. best practice atm is to have the dog wear the splint, rest and wait.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438428

If this was my dog I would go see a orthopedic specialist pronto. A dog needs to be able to move freely and painless in order to live a good life imo. This will most likely develop arthritis that causes chronic pain if only left splinted. I made the mistake once to have a leg fracture fixed by a general vet, never again because they fucked it up and the dog had to get surgery again to fix their shit by an orthopedic specialist. Dog broke a different leg eight months later and straigth to the specialist it was.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438904
Pitbulls aren't "aggressive" in strict autistic terms, the instinctive drive to attack shit from the wolf was broadened, altered, and made more tenacious so all the stalking and pouncing is removed, they only bite, shake, and that's it, no letting go. Sometimes they eat their victim. The pitbull's brain processes it as fun and it's also like the first "emotion" they default to when they're overloaded from stress or excitement. Broad headed, flat faced dogs are correlated with reduced limbic systems in the brain so their emotions aren't exactly in control.

Technically, border collies (30-50lbs) are some of the most aggressive dogs. They growl, bare teeth, and snap at the air more than most other dogs. They also have 0 fatalities to their name and their bites have a less than 1% chance of requiring more medical attention than a bandaid. All the different kinds of pitbull pass temperament tests with flying colors but go into murder mode easily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438904
Pit bulls have a genetically low threshold for arousal, that means it takes less to engage their prey drive, which is helpful for dog fighting as it improves their drive to fight. That doesn't mean they are always trying to kill things, just that smaller things can set them off. That's also affected by stress, with more stress worsening and lowering that threshold, depending on how stable your dogs temperament is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438937
They descend from terriers used for rat hunting and bulldogs that were used for hog hunting and bull baiting, which is 100% prey drive 0% aggression bloodsport. The prey drive of their ancestors makes huskies look like poodles so it's an understatement to say it takes less. Pitbulls will go after prey that's actively fighting back.

I really hate how long it takes to integrate a new puppy into a household and I came all the way to /dog/ to vent about it.
I have two schnauzers from the same litter and they will turn 5 this year. They are the most chill breed of dog on their earth. They sleep peacefully on the sofa while I work and look out the window. When you want to play, so do they. They walk when you want to walk. You feed them in the morning and let them do their thing. I do remember when they were puppies it was a hassle, but they also had each other to play with. They also kept each other company.
Now with this new puppy, my idea was to give my larger of the two schnauzers I have a new dog to play with (he's male) because his litter mate (female) is quite small and can't keep up with him when he plays she also likes to sleep twice as much as he does, I think she enjoying snuggling more than anything else in this world. Now I'm about a week in and they "get along" but this puppy is bouncing off the walls. She barely knows how to walk on a leash despite walking her multiple times a day, showing her how the other dogs walk, etc, she needs constant attention or she screams, she also wants to bite literally everything, including me and the dogs. Now my dogs are patient and they put up with her constant biting for a little bit but even they have a limit. And then it turns into them chasing each other around the house and constant barking. So when she's bad, I put her in time out and she just screams and screams. I guess I forgot how much work it is to integrate a new puppy but I'm a week in and I feel like tearing my hair out. I just want my dogs to be happy and chill with me while I work from home. Sorry for blog posting, but I needed to get this out.

Do you have any tips for grooming a long haired gsd? Was he a double coat long hair? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4433791
Yeah, he was double coated. A slicker brush will do you for most things, but it won't touch major tangles on a dog with fur that long. If you aren't brushing every day, and I probably only managed twice a week, you're probably going to want a mat-breaker. It doesn't work on my shorter coated dogs, but damn it was a godsend for my long-coated fellow. They look nasty, but it's a lot easier to cut yourself with a mat-breaker than it is to harm the dog.

If you get all the snags out, line combing with a greyhound comb will get rid of any impacted undercoat. It's a pain in the ass to get rid of snags, though, and even dogs with shorter coats have them, they're just less obvious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4433802
Do your reccomend the one specifically in your image, or is one like this better/worse? Is it okay to cut all that hair out, or will it only cut/split tangles with the sharp blades?

We have actually made quite a bit of progress on brushing. At first he was dead set on killing any sort of brush O had in my hand, but now he stays still and lets me brush him while he eats some treats from my hand. Same deal with the high velocity dryer. One day I'm hoping he will simply stay still while I brush him.

I like brushing/ grooming/ drying him actually. It feels good to care about him. Same sorta thing with spending time on meal prep as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4433830
I find the blades on those ones a little short. If you've got a mat in your GSD's trousers, you really want a long-bladed mat-breaker. It will only cut through tangles, won't cut out all the fur.

My younger GSD doesn't mind being brushed at all. He was a bit fussier about having his nails trimmed for the first month or two, but I worked on that very early and very deliberately. My late old fellow hated being groomed. He used to throw screaming tantrums as a youngster when I brushed him. As an old fellow I'm put him in a down, ask him to roll onto his side, and then gently put my hand on his shoulder while I brushed him, and he was fine with that. Patience and consistency will get you everywhere.

2 cup spent grain
1 cup whole wheat flour

1 egg

Roll out, bake at 350 for 30 minutes

You can use a bone shaped cookie cutter for your gsd, or a child shaped one for your pittie.

>>4417092
Most of the slower growing more arid new world species are supposed to tolerate it pretty well, basically your Aphonopelma, Grammostola and Brachypelma and probably some of the less common genera from similar climates. That said, you always want to do it as close to the ground as possible because they're extremely fragile and you also want to make sure to check the temperament before you try to handle by gently touching the animal with a brush or something.

Overall I'd still recommend against it though, the animal gets nothing out of it and there's always a pretty significant risk of killing it if anything goes wrong

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4422334
Their availability nowadays isn't so bad, but I guess their prices vary a lot between Europe and the US. In EU you can get L2 for 12-16€ each, while I've seen Americans ask for like $40 which I guess discourages people from buying larger groups to breed themselves and help making them more accessible.

I think their care is managable if you already have some mantis experience and are dedicated, but it's a species where it's really best to go all in and keep a group in a large setup and eventually try to breed them. Throughout the nymph stages they aren't even that bad, they just need it hot and dry in a well-ventilated cage. Once they are subadult it gets more tricky because they need a lot higher humidity and the final molts are just generally risky and ultimately involve some luck to not go badly, which is why keeping a bunch of them helps so that a mismolt doesn't completely screw you over. When I kept them I self-built netcages with branches glued to the top for better gripping during molts, that worked quite well. Breeding just didn't work out for me because I ended up with only one male, who grew faster than the females and was already a geriatric by the time they became ready to mate and he couldn't connect despite his willingness to do so.

Other empusids like Blepharopsis mendica and Gongylus gongylodes are cool alternatives that are less expensive and demanding, but somewhat similar to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428948
If you can drop daytime humidity to about 50-60% you could do a group of Phyllocrania paradoxa. Very frequently available, very easy to care for, calm and low cannibalism risk in a sizable tank with good structures and enough food. The females also can have a variety of colorations.

The rainforest species that can be kept communally are on the smaller side, some pretty hard to care for and possibly also hard to get, maybe not even available in the US. They would ideally also have some degrees higher temperature. Those would be mantids like Haania sp., Stenophylla lobivertex, Astyliasula phyllopus, or Ceratomantis sp.. Odontomantis would also work and should be more commonly available, but they're really small as adults and pretty basic looking mantids after all.

Not for groupkeeping, but as a bigger, exotic looking rainforest species you could also consider a Deroplatys desicatta/trigonodera/lobata/truncata or Parablepharis kuhlii. They look really nice and at least for mantis standards their lifespans tend to be a bit on the longer side. A slightly higher temp range of about 77-81F would be good for those though.

Also make sure that your tank's ceiling is covered in mesh, mantids will frequently strife towards higher spots and will end up hanging from the top in captivity a lot of the time. That also gives them convenient space for molting.

>>4415189
People will recommend something like Brachypelma but you'd be bored to death. I've got one that hasn't eaten (despite being offered food) in TWO years. You'll want something fast growing (faster growth rates=more eating), inexpensive, and tolerant of light.

An example of a good spider with these characteristics is a nhandu chromatus. It will eat a lot, looks cool, and won't spaz out when you turn the light on. Also, it's cheap. i got one for £3 spiderling, or £10 juvenile.

If you are into webs I would get a curtain web. I've got a Linothele megateloides. It's a mygalomorph so will live a long time like a tarantula, but the spider will web a lot more. My one, presently about the size of a house spider, has webbed up a box about 1'x1'x'8" floor to lid and side to side.

Or you could be a cookie cutter and get a Chromatopelma cyaneopubescens (greenbottle blue). It webs a bit and will eat enough to entertain, but it needs more water than people in the hobby think.

Also don't handle them. I'll pick them up sometimes for practical reasons (escapes etc.) but they get nothing from it. If you want hands on get a mammal.

They were able to contact me because my sister was cleaning out storage and found her old IPhone 2, which had my number. Another reason they contacted me was that dad had contracted some type of "life-threatening" cyst and thought it'd be best to let me know. I decided to mend our relationship because I thought I'd be an asshole just telling them that It sounds like their problem if he dies.

I had later found out that the cyst had developed because he didn't go to the doctor to get it checked. He was in the hospital for weeks getting pumped full of medicine because he had waited to the last second to go to the hospital. Because of this, he almost died.

It really only depends on:
>quality and viability of the seeds
>how you store them
My butternut pumpkin seeds are four years old and from the four I plant every year, at least two still sprout. Same with my mangold, but here it's around 90%. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431957
Seeds in plant trays. Don't direct sow. Most culinary herbs are in the lamiaceae family and they have tiny seeds and seedlings that take forever to get started. It's way easier to start those things now in trays indoors and baby them until they get big enough for transplanting. Grow more than you think you'll need. Having too many plants is a good problem to have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4436012
>I tried a Venus flytrap
It probably died because you kept it indoors. They're outdoor plants that will die if they don't get a cold dormancy.

Something easy to care for, that will also actually catch your fungus gnats, is a Pinguicula. See if you can find a P. gigantea, otherwise just get a cheap P. 'Weser' or so. All Mexican Pinguicula species and hybrids would work, but the benefit of P. gigantea is that both sides of the leaves are sticky so it can catch double the gnats, and most importantly it doesn't go dormant. The other Mexican Pinguicula go dormant during the darkest months of the year, and will then grow somewhat succulent, non-sticky leaves.

>>4436080
Nice Albuca, too. Just remember that after it's flowered, the big bulb will die back, but new bulbs will grow for next year, so don't throw it out thinking it died.

posts.com:
Plum tree I planted last year is flowering. Last year I decided to use my backyard and I planted 4 plums, 4 cherries, 4 pears, 6 apples, 5 peaches, two rows of blackberries, 8 blueberries, a row of raspberries, a handful of elderberries I found on the clearance rack at lowes, and a mix of day neutral and June bearer strawberries. Oh, and some grapes. A mix of concord, Niagara, and some wine grape that Stark Bros threw a couple of in with an order.

Looking forward to getting berries and potentially some peaches this year. I was surprised how much some of the plants grew, and I'm seeing heavy amounts of buds on some of the better plants.

I planted a massive excess of everything mostly because the deer here are simply obscene and I wanted insurance against their predation and potentially damaging or killing some of the trees. So far so good but they fucked up several of the trees last year, although they seemed to recover...

Most of the trees were bare root semidwarf varieties purchased from online nurseries. A few, like these plums, are full sized (they're going to essentially be taking the place of some old Bradford pears that the previous homeowner stupidly decided to use as a windbreak).

No point, just sharing. Looking forward to them breaking dormancy and seeing them shoot up soon. I'm expecting at least a little bit from everything other than the cherries within two years from now.

>>4438573
I wouldn't bother with the humic acid, the way humic acid largely benefits plants is lowering soil pH and acting as food for micrograms to break it down. Humic acids are to complex for plants to use so they have to be broken down first by other organisms which it then becomes dank plant food. If you are using normal fertilizer I wouldn't bother, it would be overkill. Any balanced fertilizer that is slow releasing is fine to use. To get giga succulents the main thing I have found is very well draining soil + frequent watering and of course good lighting

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4439148
Joe Hollis, Mountain Gardens. It's the first week of October and I'm here in the lower garden. If you look just over there you can see some leaf mold we're working on. All around the property you'll see these hoops with leaves piled up. We're making leaf-molllllld. It's great compost. You just let leaves decompose in place and in two years you have fantastic compost. Now if you want to speed that process up you can dump urine on it. Urine contains compounds that can help speed the activity of microorganisms that break down the structure of the dry leaves. We save our urine here, and we'll go out and periodically give our leaf piles a splash, and then stir em' up a bit to keep them from compressing too much and going anaerobic. Urine, a valuable and free source of nitrogen... for your garden.

No I don't mean to say it's a scam just that is very specific use case. If your backyard had high pH and low organic content like sand then using humic acid a few times a year would be a very cost effective way to make the soil better short of replacing it all with actually better soil. The lower pH and compounds the humic acid breaks down into are genuinely measurable benefits for plants, but in your case you already have peat moss based soil, fertilizers, and slower growing plants ie the succulents. It would be very extra.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4439295
Glass plates are one of the things tested right now. To be more specific, aquaponic grown Numex Twilight, with a glass ceiling set to 12", to force the plants into a max height. The plants bend up towards the light after meeting up with the ceiling. Center growth slows down, and the branches grow much longer than in normal growth. Lighter, smaller peppers, to keep the plants from breaking.

With led, the bottom tray's light source is connected to the aquaponic tank of the one on top of that. Cools the leds, warms up the water.

Heat and water cause condensation to form on the glass, the leaves touching the glass are mold sensitive. In this specific experiment, a central ozone generator and 2 fans per layer for forced circulation keep mold down..

Going further with squishing- Brassica Juncea, "Asian Mustard", grows very well with a 5" ceiling. 4" apart, cutting the leaf when it gets in the way of other plants.. Using a cabinet with 4 shallow drawers, lower output leds on the blueish side of the spectrum, and slightly fertilised potting soil. 3mm glass panel on top, leds mounted on the underside of the drawer above.

Only real enemy so far is the fungus gnat. Been harvesting for a family of 4 for over 3 years now, starting at 3,5 weeks from sowing- replacing the plants every 5 months, cutting down when they start to think about flowering. Keep them cool and you'll have a hardy, tasty leaf vegetable that you can harvest year round.
If it only gets slightly below freezing temps, outside harvesting goes yearround too.

>>4430499
Yes. Getting pair of bonded cats, or kittens that will grow up together if brought home at the same time, is considered a good choice. However getting only one cat is not a bad thing; just make sure to give it plenty of attention when you are back home, play with it every day and let it take part in your activities, when possible.
A small house will necessarily have to be enriched with at least one big cat tree, cardboard box(es), a cat tunnel and if possible wall shelves. And of course toys.
Remember, cats need to use vertical space too.
I am for adopting at cat shelters, but if you are oriented for a specific breed do thorough research and select a reliable breeder.

I think you should test your cat's blood first.

1) Give him some more playtime with the goal of wearing him out (you don't have to work a cat hard or long to get them huffing and puffing).
2) Look at how much food you're giving him. Just think of you at that age and how many groceries you could stuff in your fucking face before you felt full. 3)Get a plush dog toy for your cat, and use that to shove in his face when he's getting feisty. Its built for a dog to thrash and bite so its going to hold up against a cat, and it gives them something fuzzy to fight.
4) It is definitely time to get him neutered since he's right at the age where he's going to start spraying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4434567
Is he just doing it unprovoked, or is it when you're petting him and he freaks out for "no reason."
If its the later, cat's are really prone to over-stimulation, basically their brain hits a limit of how "good" something feels and they just short circuit and attack the source of the stimuli. Best advice is watch the cat's tail. If it starts twitching then take a break.
If he's just having a faggot attack you don't have to hurt the cat to let him know who's boss. If he attacks your arm then pin him to the ground and put your weight on him. Not enough to hurt the cat, but enough to get through his cat-brain and impress upon him just how badly he would get fucked up if he really wants a square go.
If you notice the cat is doing his aggressive stalking then try to defuse the situation before it happens.
Collect the plastic lids from yogurt, cream cheese, sour cream, whatever. They make really good frisbees and I've never met a cat yet that won't drop what its doing to chase it down a hall, or smack it out of the air. I think they're a little better than yarn balls or other cat toys because they move slower and have better hang time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4435296
Just keep an eye on him and let him explore. He can probably navigate better while he's smaller and get the curiosity out, and he can't jump as high. Just don't lock him in a basement by accident, let him jump into a laundry chute or let him disappear behind the TV for 5 hours before checking on him. He'll always want to go under your bed even as an adult. Easy enough to coax out by calling or shaking treats or food.
If he takes an interest in biting cables then find some covers or block the area off with anything you can wedge into the area, tape cut up trash bags over the openings. The one area we had problems with was between the counter and refrigerator and we just shoved a small box for a tablet in there. Didn't even block all of it off but made him decide he wouldn't fit.

You will give the cat a nickname just because you hate using a long name. Repeating their name is an easy way to get their attention if one call doesn't do it. There's a reason almost every cat will respond to kitty kitty kitty right off the bat, it's the sound and tone.
Mikey is probably better than Bartholomew.

I was afraid of rolling on my kitten too but found out I was hyperaware of him. I'm not normally a light sleeper but I would wake up mid turn if I so much as touched him or shifted in his direction.
If you take sleeping pills or flop around like a fish maybe rethink it but after a night or two you'll probably lose all those concerns. The cat isn't without some self preservation either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4436989
First of all, bring it indoors. Don't let it outside, the lifespan of an outdoor cat is less than half that of an indoor cat. Go to PetCo, buy a litterbox and litter, and show the cat where the box is. He'll use it.
Second, yes take him to the vet. At least get a rabies vaccine in case he escapes the house and gets bit by a rabid raccoon. If you owners left him then they don't want him so don't worry about a microchip,
Third, start him on flea medicine pronto. A 6-month box of Advantage is crazy expensive but it's cheaper and easier than de-fleaing your house.
Fourth, "cat maintenance" really isn't a thing unless you have some weird longhair breed. He'll maintain himself. Just put down food and water.

They bite your ankles and you can't even squish them they're so small. I hate fleas. I put Advantage on my cats every month. Also protects against intestinal parasites.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4437273
The more snug the better honestly.
If you give a cat the room to freak out, it will.
Should be the length of the cat laying down. Make sure it has ventilation.
If both ends can zip and on the top thats the best since getting the cat in there can be tricky.
If you're flying somewhere get ready for the cat to not shut the fuck up the entire trip.
Don't feed it for at least 12 hours before, and try to limit its water intake.
Call a vet to get the right dosage, but children's benadryl with no asprin is a cheap and safe way to sedate the cat.
I flew across the pacific with two cats and four hours in to our 17 hour flight I was ready to flush them down the fucking toilet.

posts.com:
My mom was always kind of an animal hoarder growing up and it put me off to the idea of having pets. I resented having to take care of every critter she'd pull off the street. When she moved away to make this big sort of do or die move out of state, she asked me to take care of my teenage sister and a veritable plethora of animals (long list) while they got settled. I'd take care of the house and kid and pets for a few months and they'd take over half the bills. A few months turned into over a year, and they quit sending money for the bills resulting in having to take a second job and supplement with asking around for odd jobs, and get a roommate who ended up more trouble than she was worth. It was a lot of stress for a guy in his early twenties.

Luckily my sis has always been very responsible from a young age so she took over the critters, let me know what they needed. She's a good kid though, never one for trouble or teenage shenanigans.

Ma finally came back to move everything, take my sis and get the animals, but one of the skittish cats made himself impossible to remove from the basement for days so I got stuck with him, and another was so attached to me I offered to keep him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4439814
The first real regret came after the skittish cat kind of just... Laid down one day and died. I suspect it was loneliness, his whole family had just disappeared. I felt fucking awful.
The second was when I'd been fucked over by like 2 people on rent for the the Nth time and decided to kick them out and move. Moved in with a nice old hippy lady with empty nest syndrome that loved animals, so my cat wouldn't be a problem. Turned out she left the door open all the time when mine was an indoor cat his whole life. Well I couldn't lock him up so I kinda just let the fates decide. My cat didn't stray from the porch for months until making longer forays. Eventually he never came back. Didn't see him for weeks until I saw his stupid ass on the adjacent block during a run and he came bounding up and chirping at me and acting like he was lost but he knew what the hell he was up to, dumbass just didn't want to go home.

This lesbian couple were feeding him and letting him hang out on the porch. Turns out he had chased off most of the other local cats, and became Gigachad boss of the block. I brought him home and he stuck around for a few days, but he chose a new home in his own way I guess. They were chill about it, we made friends and I'd bring cat food when coming to visit. Eventually moved out of there and I have basically no idea what he's doing. It's been about 5 years and we'd had him for a long time, so if he hasn't died of old age by now he's probably still chilling. I mostly regret feeling like I didn't come visit him enough, but it makes me happy he got to experience so much late in life in a sleepy neighborhood, away from traffic, and choosing his own way. Kinda feels like the true good ending.

I live vicariously through other people's pets now. Picrel, the man himself.

IDK if this is the right thread because I don't frequent /an/, but I have a burning question: Based on what's known about Hypsilophodon, is it accurate for it to be this funny chicken that spits acid?
https://isle.fandom.com/wiki/Hypsilophodon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4394215
That complex feathering is probably far beyond the filaments and proto-feathers that actually would have adorned the animal so it would have looked more like a plucked turkey.
>spits acid
We'll probably never be able to know something like that, though maybe the animal's teeth would show the effects of continuous exposure to stomach acid. It probably wouldn't be used as a blinding agent, but there are a number of birds that vomit on themselves or vomit on their attackers as a defensive mechanism. So It might have been possible that Hysilophodon could have used vomit oil in a similar way as Fulmar chicks or it could use a mix of spit and vomit to try and blind animals similar to camels.
Without any evidence of these behaviors in Hypsilophodon I can't really call it accurate, but it's not impossible for it to have used vomit as an anti-predator mechanism.

I've been working on a space setting where most lifeforms are not humanoid [spoiler] the plot/lore being that humanity despite expanding through the cosmos are already on the bringe of extinction, with the most optimistic numbers calculating that there's at best 1000 or so humans alive, even counting a place called "The Sanctuary" which is a small human zoo in the middle of an alien megatropolis that has tried to work on preservation programs, planet Earth being even to most humans just a myth and not even in some cases not even marked on galactic maps [/spoiler] making humans more unique

I've been trying to do some and one idea I had was that of slime life that uses mecha containers to move in places that's not their world similar to picrel (altho that's more of a dieselpunk magic magma creature)
I don't wanna do everything 100% realistic but grounded instead so Im looking for inspiration
Thanks for the help in advance

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400460
You want to qualify these questions:
>What level of nervous system do they have? Unicellular, Cnidarianesque, Molluskesque, Tetrapodesque?
>Are they amorphous or semirigid? If they're amorphous, how do they protect themselves and navigate the world? How do they manipulate the world? Semirigid will have a much easier time here.
>How did they attain intelligence and tool use, and how well-versed in it are they? Are they more intelligent and well-situated for whatever niche they inhabit, or are they really good at using tools but not the biggest brainiac?
My personal recommendation is to go with a cephalopod-esque intelligence and make them deep-sea dwellers that can contort their bodies easily but discovered tool use as an excellent way to preserve them and their kin. You can easily make whalefalls/driftwood equivalents more common on their home world for native materials and a source for them to tread upwards. Bonus: deep-sea dwelling creatures often survive trips to the surface easily, so it would make them look even more blobbish but without any risks to their functionality. It would also give them precedence for wearable devices or containers for respiration or similar so you can move forward with your initial idea if you so choose. Just remember to not make them literal octopus/squids. Try searobins+blobfish as the basis, maybe.

>>4400460
I have an idea though it's evolutionarily dodgy imo.

First off, we have real slime life forms on earth: slime molds. Despite being single celled organisms that don't have anything even close to a brain they're apparently capable of some degree of cognition (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/04/160427081533.htm?trendmd-shared=0). Even better for you, they're capable of fusing together into super-cells and apparently can share that knowledge (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/12/161221090246.htm)
I hope you're serious about it not being 100% realistic because here's were it gets a little dodgy, lets pretend that enough of them fuse together allows to develop something approaching or even surpassing human intelligence either with this weird cell memory or using millions of cell nuclei as some kind of central nervous system or maybe having some kind of unique organelles to function as a cns. Either way, they're still basically a living puddle of snot so they'd need some kind of powered exoskeleton to do much of interest but I'm not sure how they'd make one in the first place regardless of what their environment is like. Maybe they got some help from some other species and have since gained independence.

>All those extra vertebrae

Vertebrae number is tied to specific genes, so if you start fucking with that you also trigger a fuckton of genetic disorders and abnormalities. That's why giraffes have the same number of neck vertebrae as humans; they can't mutate more without screwing up the rest of the body.

Started to play around with domestication yesterday. Vucum's ch'ceri means 'friend of the people' and is a very trusting creature. It's been bred into two types: tinur [working] and cssin'rt'ust [transportation]. It's also the only species whose back legs fused due to a mutation that just stuck around. It allows for greater pushing/pulling strength.
The plant came to me in a dream. Its spikes have red tips and are coated in poison, fresh leaves are blood red and slowly become light green. It's about four meters tall and lives in tight rain forests where the spikes, once piercing neighbouring plants, kill them to make room for more sunlight.
The two things on the left are scrapped concepts because I feel like they're not very creative. Bottom one was supposed to be a domesticated later evolution form of the one above. Markings are drawn on, not natural. Front pair of legs developed into tough claws to fight off opponents and grab small prey.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been thinking about how aquatic mammals could come across a large, distant island that no other large mammals have yet colonized, and re-evolve a terrestrial lifestyle (nevermind the awkward wobbling pinnipeds already do). I have three main questions about this idea:

- What pressures would there be for pinnipeds (the most likely candidate; cetaceans would be too anatomically awkward) to evolve terrestriality? Sure, with little to no competition, they can radiate like hell with all the new food sources give a couple million years, but what would convince a population of them to totally leave the water?

- I've noticed that practically all aquatic mammals (besides otters, I guess) have blubber. Why is that - how necessary is it? I can see it being necessary for cold temperate waters, but what about sunbaked tropical coastal waters? Would it be possible for a population of pinnipeds to become "skinny" again if they keep to warm tropical waters?

- How plausible is it for the hind flippers to become more "leg-like" and aid in terrestrial locomotion?

Adding to this anon: mammals are endothermic. They lose body temperature very quickly in water, even in tropical regions. That's why the Amazon river dolphin still has 4cm of blubber. There was a video of stranded common dolphins that explained that they lose heat much faster on land than in water and once they started to shiver, the rescue team had to spray them with seawater. Don't know how relevant this is but whatever.

>>4434925
Here in Finland, we spay a lot of mutts and cats. Shelters are very active in here and captures any roaming pets. If you want your captured pet back, it will cost (sometimes a lot). Technically, it's legal to shoot stray cats in your own land. If your pet keeps all the time roaming freely, you can technically get a fine for abandoning a pet according to the law. It's a little bit of gray area. So there are many reasons why to reduce the risk of the pet running away is highly encouraged. WHAT IS SPECULATIVE EVOLUTION?
Speculative evolution is the exploration and imagining of how life might evolve in the future or could have evolved in alternate pasts. It's a multimedia sci-fi genre that harnesses scientific principles to create detailed and plausible hypothetical creatures, ecosystems, and evolutionary histories.

RESOURCES:
https://speculativeevolution.fandom.com/wiki/Category:Tutorial
>One-stop shop for relevant background information for starting a project

>The Speculative Evolution forums, full of resources and ongoing projects

>The Serina project, a seed world of evolved birds.

http://www.cmkosemen.com/snaiad_web/snduterus.html
>Snaiad, an exploration of life on an alien planet.

I'm rebooting an old idea of mine, an alternative Earth history where insects become the primary large land animals in the Carboniferous. These highly derived insect-descendants form a clade called the Lepidozoa. Basically, insect-dinosaurs.

So far I've drawn a generic herbivore and carnivore to establish basic Lepidozoan head anatomy. The carnivore is a bear-like species with powerful sabre-mandibles. The herbivore is something like a pig or goat. It's got a long beak for picking through leaf litter. Herbivorous Lepidozoans often have mandibles more like tusks or antlers.

>>4438371
Lepidozoans have several adaptations for overcoming insect size limits. The ancestral exoskeleton has evolved into a more flexible integument I’m calling “mosaic cuticle”: small studs of chitin embedded in skin, similar to osteoderms in reptiles.

Mosaic cuticle is more flexible than an exoskeleton, and most importantly can grow along with the animal without needing to be periodically shed.

Pic related is an infographic I made for this project years ago. The illustration is outdated (I’m reworking the project from scratch), but most of the information in the description is still valid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Worked in a pig farm.
Honestly my favourite job yet. I did come home everyday smelling like shit, waking up at 3AM was annoying and some of the coworkers were assholes.
But otherwise, loved it. If I still had my notes with all the schedules it would be like this:
>4AM, prepare milk for the piglets and feed them
>5-6AM scrape the shit in the piglets kennel
>6AM Sows feeding time, give them and their piglets vitamins and feed, scrape the shit as the sows wake up and get fed through the automatic feeder
>7AM some free time, go to the office to have a coffee, read a book etc...
>8AM Go srape/wash away (depended on the temperature of the day) shit from the not-yet-pregnant sows hall
>9AM Go feed piglets and scrape their shit again
>10AM Go feed the momma pigs and their piglets, scrape their shit, again. (Yes, a lot of shit scraping)
>11AM all work done for today and all thats left is to wait for the afternoon shift to come in and update them about what happened that day and I could go home.
There we a lot of cats, as rats were common (hunted them with a plank), my 2 favourite cats was a small black cat I called Lil' Nigga and a Cripple for being a bit crippled (cattarct in one eye and fucked up ear), they both smelled constanly like shit.
Yes, I did have to deal with my fair share of dead pigs. The piglets were easy, just chuckem in a bucket and done. When swines died that was a problem, they are heavy, and you have to drag them outside so you can actually load them up on the tractor.
Pic related

I had a vision in my sleep last night. As distinguished from a dream which is mere sorting and cataloguing of the day's events by the subconscious. This was a vision, fresh and clear as a stream in Central Kalimantan- the mind revealing itself to itself. In my vision, I was on the veranda of a vast feeding platform, a Peron Makan of some fantastic proportion.
There seemed to emanate from it a light from within - this gleaming radiant jungle. I had known this place. I had in fact been born and raised there. This was my first return, a reunion with the deepest wellsprings of my being. Wandering about, I was happy that the forest had been immaculately maintained. There had been planted a number of additional trees, but in a way it blended so seamlessly with the original canopy, one would never detect any difference. Returning to the jungle's grand treescape, there came a knock from above. Budi was standing there. He was happy and care-free, clearly living a life of deep harmony and joy. We embraced - a warm and loving embrace, nothing withheld. We were in this moment one. My vision ended. I awoke with a tremendous of optimism and confidence in pongos and their future.

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4435243
Their care is pretty simple really, you could dump them into most community fishtanks and they'd do well as long as it's properly escape-proofed. Just a layer of substrate because they like digging(and will frequently uproot plants while doing so) and dark hiding spots and they're fine. They are basically clawfrog levels of simple, without the part where they eat everything else in the tank. That's also why it's sad that they have gotten so rare, they are easy and cool aquarium herps that could be staples in the hobby like axolotls, ribbed newts or clawed frogs if there were more breeders. They might not produce a ton of offspring at once, but with a breeding group you could still get a few dozen babies per year.

No, because they have no reason to interact with each other.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4436704
Leopard Geckos have fairly specific care requirements, outside of which they have health problems. They're not really appropriate to free roam in 70F/50% humidity that most human houses roughly target.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4436704
In case your actually being serious, I'll list a few.

1. You shouldn't be feeding reptile insectivores random insects, nor letting them "hunt" bugs around your house. Why? Because of parasite risk and lack of proper nutrition. Also, who knows what the fuck the insects that roam around your house are eating that could pass to your gecko.
2. Your gecko wouldn't have any proper enrichment or husbandry standards roaming around your house. How are they going to bask? How are they going to get UVB/D3? How are they going to get their vitamins and calcium? How are they going to find moist places to shed? Warm places to digest food? Etc. Etc.
3. Your leopard geckos will inevitably fight, and then hurt/kill themselves over resources. Leopard geckos aren't animals that like to be around each other much, which is why leopard gecko cohabitation is frowned upon.
4. Do you want salmonella carrying reptiles roaming freely unchecked around your house?
5. They will inevitably track a larger predator into your house given enough time.
6. How are you going to provide reptile level heating gradients and humidity for an entire house? (And no, a large heat pad isn't an answer to this, retard).
7. If you really wanted to just kill insects by letting another animals roams free, you could just get some fucking spiders instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438718
>Anyways, how long do I need to wait to add substrate after siliconing background together?
24-48 hours, or until it no longer smells like the worlds worst salad dressing.
Also, use disposable tools and gloves when you work with silicone. Tongue depressors, plastic flatware, etc. Additionally, moisture causes it to prematurely cure, so make sure the shit you want it to stick to is as dry as possible, and the shit you DONT want it to stick to is wet (but keep in mind the silicone you touch with the wet shit wont want to stick as well to dry shit anymore.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438745
he can eat cuttlebone whenever he wants to. mine had an insane hunger for it one day, he ate (more like destroyed) half of it... and then he didnt touched the rest for 6weeks. mine also likes cactus pieces, its rally funny to see whats their current favorite food.
but in general regarding feeding, give him the good stuff from your hand so he can bound better with you, but dont give him too much sweet stuff, all of the suggar gives his gut microbiota a boost and this will give him a bad stinky. some is nice, too much is not so nice. btw tutels can also get fat (if they eat way too much protein rich foods like glover), but this should not be a problem if he can eat in your garden whatever he likes and can walk around. its the best way if he can choose, because they usually eat what they need.
also a tip: he is living close to the ground, snails will try to get to his food or even eat from it which risk that he will get some snail parasites (like roundworms). it might be helpful to give some of his fresh poop to the vet so he can look for such parasites (maybe once a year or so) therefor... keep his feeding/living place as snail free as possible (pick em up and throw them away)
also, they are cute and like scratches but hate it if they are carried around by hand, they want to stay in touch with the ground (they are afraid of hights, you can see it in their eyes). i use a flower pot base plate to carry him around in it (and to bath him), its a less stressful way to get him from A to B.
in general... there is so much to know, i am sure there is a good book out there to read up on all of such little issues.

>>4412014
>One theory explaining the highly unsual habit of H. zschokkei and its fellow myxosporeans invokes the cancers of cnidarians. On this explanation, animals such as H. zschokkei were originally cancerous growths in free-swimming jellyfish that escaped their parent organism and thereafter became a separate species parasitizing other animals. Such an origin is referred to as a SCANDAL (Speciated by CANcer Development in AnimaLs).[10]

Ah, the old HeLa/transmissible dog cancer dynamic strikes again. This reminds me how any animal, technically, just depends on its germ line. It sounds trivial, but it becomes more fascinating the more think about it: we ultimately only depend on the genetic code that belongs to the sperm/egg. Meaning if some cosmic ray strikes you gonads, all your descendants will have that change (simplified). If the entire rest of the body receives a trillion cosmic rays, your progeny will not care and not be affected. You -- the person that is you -- literally just sources from ball cells.
As said, it sounds trivial, but also strange.

Some people say pets are parasites. But this is because they don’t understand what the pet actually does or how (in fact they are antisocial and low empathy and never will). The pet replaces them. The obligatory friend who is just a friend and does very little, but highly social people need that no strings attached relationship to stay sane and evolving to lack the need for one at all would make them worse in other ways. Pets are a symbiote that allows us to remain highly social and replace potentially dangerous and resource intensive non-productive humans with something exponentially safer and cheaper. Objectively less unneeded human contact lessens your risk of being killed or stolen from. All of your human friends should be productive enough to make up for that risk, but that creates stressful obligations and friendships that can never be relied on. The useless friend is the best one to confide in and rely on just to fulfill your instincts.

They are an inevitable and essential part of an efficient high trust society but they must be that. Friends, fwbs. Not children. Or they stop being a symbiote. It’s like your gut flora moving to your body cavity - nope!

Jellyfish reproduction has an asexual and sexual stage. It starts with the medusae fertilizing an egg with sperm like most animals, then this originates a larva, that after a while will find a place to settle and develop into a polyp that looks sort of like an anemone. After a while (they can stay in this stage for years) the polyp will split into several medusae and the cycle will start anew.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4432081
>that's because eusociality is the highest step in social evolution. we just have yet to reach it
Debatable. While humans have only very limited biological reproductive specialisation (menopause), our behaviour is highly eusocial.
Laying down your life to the benefit of others in your community is a fundamentally eusocial behaviour. The poppy fields of flanders are only possible if your species, or society, values supporting the reproductive success of the collective over the reproductive success of the individual. Human willingness to go to war and die for the benefit of the collective is a fundamentally eusocial behaviour.
And the reason eusocial species are as successful as they are isn't simply their mode of reproduction. It's the behavioural changes this mode of reproduction enables. If these same behavioural changes are possible without changing the mode of reproduction, the impact on the ecosystem is still the same.
And that's before we get into humans not having a high degree of biologically sourced reproductive specialisation, but very much having a high degree of social reproductive specialisation. Wealth used to be an important determinant in whether a human could reproduce or not. A large percentage of humans still worked for their respective polities, but never got to breed, simply by way of social enforcement. Crucially, their work still benefitted the polity they lived in, which cannot be said for a jaguar that dies alone and without having fathered cubs. Individuals without reproductive success still added to the reproductive success of the collective.
THAT is the fundamentally difference between eusociality and not-eusociality.
And interestingly enough, there are species of wasps that function the same. Each worker CAN lay eggs from which new wasps would hatch, but social enforcement of dominance hierarchies means that only the queen (or sometimes several queens) actually does so.
Humans are on that level. Primitively eusocial.

I don't mean anything crazy but they do have a symbiotic relationship. For example termites and land-dwelling isopods eat rotting wood and rely on the gut fauna that they have(and what's in the wood breaking it down) to do the majority of the digestion for them. Hydrogen sulfide fixating bacteria symbionts aren't something seemingly too difficult to evolve as many semi-sessile and sessile organisms have developed relationships with them. For example shipworms( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shipworm ) and another trophosome haver the Paracatenula flatworms( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracatenula ). There are other chemotrophs that could potentially be used besides sulfur oxidizing ones, like nitrogen oxidizing(nitrifying) bacteria(which might make more sense as the very ammonia that the lampreys would produce from breaking down their fat and muscle tissue would produce ammonia which can then sustain those bacteria, plus anything gotten from the water that passes them by). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitrifying_bacteria

>>4439547
While platypuses do come out during the day. They are predominantly nocturnal. They have an extremely interesting social hierarchy. Basically they will share a territories and even resting burrows, but they time it out so it not at the same time. Kinda like Scandinavians at a buss stop. Usually it's the "lowest ranking" that end up foraging in the day time. That means the youngest and they tend to be the most skittish. My understanding is that the best way to get a picture of one is to basically set up an observation point somewhere they are most likely to travel through before and through dusk and dawn. If that waterway does have platypus in it you can catch a glimpse one after another timed a few minutes apart.

posts.com:
Thinking about maybe getting a rat and was curious if someone can give me a QRD on taking care of them.
>How much time do you need to dedicate to them, if I have 2 of them and they can play with each other?
>What's the general routine, do you let them chill out in their enclosure while you're not at home and let them out while you can look after them? In general how much space do they need?
>Do I have to worry about them breaking shit if I let them run around my apartment?
>In general how long at a time can they be kept in their enclosure without needing to be let out?
>How much of a problem is it that they shit and piss all over the place?
>Anything else I should be aware about?
Also from all the posts here I assume they're quite social and don't mind being picked up and played with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431491
Oh also upon some further research, it looks like rats can get sick and need to the vet quite often. What's your guys' experience been with that so far?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431491
>How much time do you need to dedicate to them, if I have 2 of them and they can play with each other?
I dedicate ~1 hour every other day to spot clean, 2 hours on Sundays for a full clean, and at least an hour every other day for free roaming. WIth only 2 rats (I have 4) you'd need to clean less often.
>What's the general routine, do you let them chill out in their enclosure while you're not at home and let them out while you can look after them? In general how much space do they need?
They stay in their critter nation when I'm gone. When I'm home from work I take them out in my apartment bathroom (I put out foraging toys, cardboard box houses, pea fishing, etc) and spot clean the cage. I'll also add some more cage enrichment and make them lil salads in addition to their main diet.
>Do I have to worry about them breaking shit if I let them run around my apartment?
they chewed up my bathroom's baseboards and a hole in my door, so yes. I fixed everything with wood filler and covered the doors with draft stoppers. They can jump like 3 feet in the air and knock over items on a table if they wanted, but mine stay in the bathroom so it's never happened. They love climbing up things so be careful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431491
>>4431700
>>4431549
>In general how long at a time can they be kept in their enclosure without needing to be let out?
I wouldn't go more than a week, but they won't die you go longer. I let them out everyday or every other day.
>How much of a problem is it that they shit and piss all over the place?
nah they're easily litter box trained. They run back into their cage to shit in the litter box. Males will leave tiny droplets of pee to scent mark things, but I just mop after playtime. My females literally never pee outside the cage.
>Anything else I should be aware about?
don't try to make a fence for free roaming. Mine spent the entire time trying to figure out how to knock over the barriers. Once I moved them into my bathroom, a proper enclosed space, they started actually playing with the stuff I laid out
>it looks like rats can get sick and need to the vet quite often. What's your guys' experience been with that so far?
They can get respiratory infections if you put heavily scented things near them. Make sure their bedding is fragrance free, and if you use fleece wash it with fragrance free detergent. If you get your rat from an ethical breeder, you won't have to worry as much about frequent health issues. If you get a feeder rat from the pet store, higher likelihood of cancer and other health/behavioral issues. Vet visits can be between $50 for a physical exam and $250 for neutering, so just have some money in case. I personally haven't had any issues with illness, but my rats are rescued from a lab where they're actually resistant to respiratory issues since they're born mycoplasma free. Cancer is common in all domesticated rats unfortunately, but many exotic vets are able to perform surgeries on them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4438805
They were all healthy controls for my project and I couldn't justify killing them when I didn't actually need to harvest any tissue. They actually have less disease than typical rats. Painstakingly bred, mycoplasma free, and resistant to a lot of cancers and infections, which is why they're like $500 each. They're not sociable with humans though and super skittish. I love them regardless.

I've had hamsters that just didn't wanna burrow. Definitely not a size issue idk what those people are on. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438862
>Whats would likely happen if the boss found you taking one home?
Don't think he'd care but each university is under strict animal care protocols to ensure the research is ethical. Since there's no formal adoption system, IACUC (American Association for Laboratory Animal Science) can't ensure that I'm caring for them properly. They could threaten my license, but many other grad students and lab techs have rescued the animals. I think the IACUC people kinda turn a blind eye.
>What are you doing with to need a control rat?
They are the mothers of the babies that I am actually experimenting on. I don't need to study the mothers, only the babies after they grow to adulthood. I study behavioral neurobiology, so I need to collect brain tissue at the end for my experimental animals. They are sacrificed ethically and don't feel a thing, but I HATE doing it. I have one male lab rat at home. He was just used to calibrate some harmless equipment.
>Where can I sign up this job?
Just find a university lab that tests on rats. If you're in college you can easily join a lab. If you're not in college you can be a lab technician. This is not glamorous and you will have to kill and dissect the rats. Don't join a lab that studies horrible diseases or else you'll see them suffering. I study behavior so it's chill besides the sacrificing. I just raise cute babies then watch them run on mazes and drink sugar. In terms of disease, I do have to give the non-control animals mild depression. It's sad, but it beats giving them cancers or strokes. I don't adopt the depressed ones because I have to study their brains.

posts.com:
I had one in my headlights a few hours ago. On the side of the road, in the spotlight, a doe squatted and urinated at about 30ft from me. Had a stare off with my headlights. When I turned them off, she initially sped off, but came back just 5 minutes later. Closing in, I spooked her at about 6 feet by telling her she was brave, meeting a scary human.

Left her some salty snacks, away from the road.

Had a meet and greet with some highland cows, they were skiddish, was a bit sketchy. Saw "my" herd of semi wild cows as well, got to spend a while near them, their smell probably masking my human scent. By doing that, got to see a few deer grazing up close. Without the cows, they'd sped off without me knowing about it.

Next to the deer and the cows, got to pet a friendly bull as well, no kicks or hornplay, so that went well. Bit of an understatement to say it went well. Anyhoo, deer. They are cute.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4437593
Call an animal shelter or animal services.
They kind of deal with that.

This shit happens when owners just set their (un neutered) buns free after realizing they can't take care of themselfs, or after realizing that their unneutered bun had babies.

If you wanna try to get them abandon the thought of catching it with your hands. This will not work. Get stuff like slices of apples or the green stems of carrots.
Your best bet is to make a larger "play pen" and put the food in there and then close it, once the bunny is in there. That way you might catch it. Make sure to make yourself as flat as possible. Be close to the ground so the bunny doesn't escape.
There isn't a good tutorial on HOW to catch rabbits, since they all sort of react different. Here are a couple of videos from people who did that, maybe it'll give you ideas.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vO4u9RQQXXY
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NzT_yucwICU

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4437726
>>4437798
shit I didn't see that you actually already did things. Yes, sometimes it is a multiple day thing. Return with food, so they start to associate you with food.
Grass and leaves are for their digestion. Keep all sorts of things:
Apples, Carrots and timothy hay. That is the good stuff they like (sugar and stuff and timothy hay because it smells nice).
I assume from the photos that you were sitting or standing, waiting for them. Lay down on the floor, get on their eye level. Otherwise they will not want to check out what is in your general direction.

Good luck, anon!!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4437798
You might be able to trap with a trap like this and fruit as bait. Don't try to catch them by hand since you will fail and the buns will become even more than their usual baseline wary.
If you're planning on taking care of them longterm then you probably want an dog exercise pen for them as their prison, and that might work as a trap itself.
Buns can survive outside ok but it isn't great. I'm not good at breed identification but those look like rhinelanders to me. Pet rabbits have had some of their survival instinct bred out of them overtime so they don't fare as well in the wild.

If you rap your knuckles on the back of a wombat it's like knocking on a door.
When attacked by a predator wombats charge down their huge burrows and squat. The predator can't bite through their back so tries to climb over them to bite their head, then the wombat does a press-up and crushes the predator to death against the roof of the burrow.
If you hit a wombat with your car it will smash your sump cover up into your crankshaft.
If a wombat gives you a playful nip it can accidentally sever your achilles tendon.
Wombats also have square poop.
I'm not making any of this up.

Wombat poop is square because they have bones either side of their turd-cutter that force the feeshus into that shape.
There might be an evolutionary advantage in that it's harder for square poop to roll or be blown or washed away from where you want it to be. It's your advertising, like your Twitter or your Tinder or whatever.
Animals are weird everywhere. It's just the fact that Australia has been so long isolated from the northern-hempishere continents that marsupials (and monotremes) evolved to fill all the niches that placental mammals do everywhere else.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4413497
Sure, maybe. I'm not claiming to know.
Koalas, like wombats, have a backwards-facing pouch -- which is also downwards-facing in the case of the koala.
This is apparently because they descend from a common ancestor that burrowed like a wombat and didn't want dirt in its pouch.
The koala, though, has evolved a sphincter muscle around the top (bottom) of its pouch so that the baby koalas don't fall out 150 feet up a gum tree.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4435893
Nah, at worst bottled bacteria is snakeoil. IMO fishless cycling is a meme though, it's ultra conservative advice we throw at novices as a counter to ultra reckless practices of yeeting goldfish in naked bowls. Once you notice life taking hold in your tank, algae growing, plants starting to grow past their melt stage, sneed shrimp and other critters developing you're safe to start stocking. If you're worried about the fish, start with a light stock and good number of water column feeding plants to kickstart the biofiltration.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4435893
As someone who used to keep fish as a young boy back in the 90s and only recently got back in to the hobby.
"Fishless cycling" is a meme, "cycling" is a real thing but no where as....involved as people make it out to be. Back in the day we did not have all these water treatments. Beneficial bacteria starters? Nope. Setting up the tank a day before and letting things settle/temperature normalize? Nope. Washing gravel? Actually yes, we did that.

Here is how we did things back then.
>go to local Petco and buy
>20g tank
>HoB
>Air pump/stone
>bright colored gravel
>plastic plants
>castle/house thing
>heater
>20 Neon Tetras
>10 Tigar Barbs
>3 "sucker fish" aka Pleccos
>An Angel Fish
>A what I now know as "African Dwarf Frog"
>go home and set up tank
>put fish bags in for 30 mins and release
>enjoy for the next few years while doing water changes one every two weeks. 100% water changes btw, we would put the fish in to buckets
Know what happened? Nothing. They did not die right away. Not even over the next few months. At least not for reasons surrounding water perimeters. It was the Angel Fish slaughtering everything that got too close or the Barbs teaming up on the Angel and nipping it to death.

Imo, you should add animals slowly. Start with invertebrates. I’m 6 weeks into my cycling and was on your situation about 3 weeks in. Nitrates, no ammonia or nitrites. I added in snails and they began shorting all over, producing ammonia. The result? The live bacteria in the tank couldn’t (and still can’t) properly consume all the ammonia and nitrites and there’s always 0.25-0.5 ppm ammonia in the water. Fishless cycling will give you very little ammonia, so the bacteria colonies don’t really even develop properly unless you add in a ton of food that has ammonia in it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4436226
pH barely matters. I know people with wild discus in well water. low pH suppresses bacteria which is the key for blackwater fish, a very clean higher pH setup will usually do fine. You might need to lower pH to stimulate breeding for some species but I am very unconvinced that anything from 6.5-8.0 actually matters. Most of the 'soft water' species you see out there are bred on Florida fish farms with liquid rock without major problems.

German Blues aren't great though imo, can be very temperamental fish. If you want a ~2-3'' apisto I recommend looking into Borellii. No heater required but does fine at tropical temps too. Found in the wild in pH ranging from 5.0-8.0, at temps from the 40s to the upper 80s. They are SLIGHTLY food picky in that it has to be moving in front of them in the lower half of the tank for them to care, but in terms of what that food is, I find they actually prefer dry over frozen. That's similar for a lot of apistos from my experience though.

(picrel is my pair, going to rehome them from a 10 to a 20 long because the female is being a bitch)

>>4436448
Boys, less shit flinging, more critical thinking. Plants can use Ammonia as a Nitrogen source just as they can use Nitrate. Nitrosomonas and Nitrobacter also colonize quite readily on plant surfaces, especially roots, so it also acts as filter media.

And before anyone starts nitpicking Ammonia vs. Ammonium, per Diana Walstad's book, which everyone here claims to have read, plants use NH4+ (Ammonium) directly, however most N broken down from fish waste, unless you have an aquarium of pH of 6.8 or lower, is Ammonia. But NH3 can diffuse into plant cells and will easily find a free H+ to become NH4+ which will then be used.

A lot of plants actually use Ammonium much easier than Nitrate, the reason why the whole cycle works the way it does is because bacteria is even faster than plants at processing Ammonia/Ammonium (and Nitrite), thus the plants have no choice to use Nitrate as in a mature system that is all that's left.

However it is mostly correct that to totally offset fauna, it generally takes a shitload of plants if you're not using any sort of traditional aquarium filter. There's a reason (well, many really) why all animals only take up about 2 Gigatons of Carbon vs. plant matter being 450 Gigatons of Carbon on the entire planet. (All other life being about 100 Gigatons of Carbon, most of that being bacteria.)

>>4438272
depends on the tail length. guppies will not try to fuck a betta. Bettas will typically hate longer finned guppy males more. Redder bettas and redder guppies are both generally more aggressive.
Bettas tend to hate livebearers in general because they're retarded chaos fish who dont really respect a betta's space. Constantly triggering the fight instinct without your betta being able to kill them can actually stress the betta, especially super long finned varieties.

Bettas are imo best paired with small schoolers who don't have a reputation for being nippy, and bottom feeders. If you want to pair them with a livebearer do endlers IMO. I find they don't mind the females and the males are a lot swifter than guppies on average.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438455
Two reasons to maybe use stratum over dirt:
>dirt takes longer to "settle" and leaches out a lot of random shit the first few weeks
>some stratums will buffer your pH and KH

So basically, stratum is a bandaid for low patience or a very hard water source used for low pH

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438459
I can understand using it for the buffering but they sell it as a planted tank 'aquasoil' when it's really not that, unless your comparing basic gravel/sand. Even with root tabs, my experience has been lacking with stratum. Also have you set up a dirted tank before, and what methods did you use? If you're dumping dirt straight in your tank as your primary substrate, then yea you'll probably have some issues. If you take a month to soak it and let it bake in the sun, that will eliminate most of you issues there. If you take it further and sift your dirt on a screen to remove the mulch and rocks, then you shouldn't have any issues with settling or nutrients. Even still you should have a small cap of gravel or sand over your dirt so it stays at the bottom. I've done this a few times with no issues out of my dirt. Hell I didn't even sift the dirt in my 75 gallon and I've never had settling issues. I've used almost innert topsoil and fertilizer/piss soaked premium potting soil with great success and very little algea. I really do think everyone who does the work up front on the dirt will have tremendous success. I just wish it was a more common practice, because I've seen some lush tanks running just gravel or just stratum. I could only imagine the growth with some good dirt. Gotta throw the plug in for Ole dirty dustin on YouTube, wouldn't know shit about dirt without his videos

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438469
The time to prep dirt is exactly what I meant as one benefit to stratum. And it works OK for planted tanks if you are heavily stocked and have something that turns the substrate a bit - it's basically like the various baked clay stuff in that it seems to absorb and transfer nutrients pretty well, and has a little more base level nutrients.

Now the worst shit I've used is Aqueon's "plant and shrimp substrate" that looks like little balls. It's so light that you can pull a sword straight out, and that's assuming anything roots. No idea if the nutrients are any good because the one time I used it, not a single plant would stay rooted for more than a week.

posts.name: Anonymous
