>And it works OK for planted tanks if you are heavily stocked and have something that turns the substrate a bit
That's probably where I fucked up with it, because I had it in a 5 gallon with just a guppy, pea puffer and there were 30 ghost shrimp that died over a couple months, but really small in terms of bioload. I did use tabs and dose some liquid ferts, but that just made the algea worse. The stratum also didn't hold roots very well, I'd have to replant alot of of my dwarf sag when I did a gravel vacuum. I'm hoping it will work better with some gravel on top to keep the plants rooted but still give the roots access to the stratum and tabs. I'm gonna try to ease in on the liquid ferts because this tank only has 1 dwarf cichlid, so maybe I can get some better growth plant growth without too much algea.

The time to prep dirt is probably my least favorite part. Nothing worse than sitting on your hands looking at an empty tank because your dirt isn't ready. I've got some mineralizing right now for any future tanks to avoid the future waiting, but I know not everyone has that luxury. I've been tempted to try and start selling my own dirt, because I think there's a huge market for it. I just lament the idea of hustling bags of dirt on ebay long enough to get going

>I'd recommend dirt over the stratum any day, but some people have great results from it.
what dirt do you use? do you have any links for how you prepped it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438610
Not that anon, but I mix my own dirt blend. Peat moss + worm castings + red clay powder used for seed bombs + biochar + any organic soil without perlite. You want to find soil that's very broken down, any wood chunks or other fillers that are their for drainage/air is completely useless for our plants in aquariums. My mix is overkill though, you can use any soil that's composted nicely and entirely made of drainage fillers.

If this is your first dirt tank seriously stay away from perlite that shit is AIDS to get out if you accidentally make a mess and you will make a mess here and there. Don't use any soil that has manure added unless it's very composted. Just remember anything not composted will rot since the lack of oxygen means composting pretty much halts in our tank substrate. picrel is lava rock base layer, soil mix, then gravel cap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438610
Organic compost will be fine. Sift out the large organics with a flour sifter.
you will want to cap it with sand or gravel.
1 inch of compost = 2 inch of cap.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4438610
I used different kinds, scotts top soil for the 75 gallon and kelloggs organic garden soil for the other 2 tanks. Like other dude said, perlite is cancer and keep it out of your tank. Organic soil is usually better and a NPK of around .10-0.05-0.05. There's no perfect way to do it, but there's some general guidelines. If you buy something from the store the biggest thing is letting it soak and dry out alot, pic related is what I follow but I usually extend soaking and drying. This helps strip out alot of the chemical additives and makes your dirt more stable. It's easiest in the summer but you can do it whenever, and I also like to let it rain on the dirt whenever I can while it's prepping. Highly beneficial to screen your dirt and sift out any mulch or rocks, and you will have a nice brown dusty sand. You can further add things like clay, crushed shells/coral, peat moss, etc. but do your homework as some things can buffer the water

ok so I'm planning on turning my 40g into a native tidepool setup with a rock gunnel etc. The problem is that everywhere I look says temperate fish need to be aggressively cooled which is a no go for me. For this reason I plan on doing a tidepool setup with creatures collected from the beach, under the impression that they should take new england summer temps fine, as they do so in nature. But I couldn't for the life of me find anything that confirmed this as correct. One even said that the tide pool creatures can survive heat for a short time but then they will die.
All of this sounds like complete bullshit to me though, like rock gunnels are literally semi aquatic, they live in wet seaweed half the time. Those pools are always going to be as warm, if not warmer than the ambient air temperature at any given time.
Can anyone give their opinion on this? I picked tide pool fish because I didn't want to blow a mortgage on a fucking cooler, but the internet says they need one too for some reason. It just doesn't make sense and pisses me off because I have been saving that tank for this purpose.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4439204
some people do, but in general it's best to never add the saltwater from the store to your tank, for risk of introducing pests
I'm not too familiar with all the pests for freshwater, but there are a TON for saltwater, from invert / parasites to algaes diatoms etc - there are also pest hitchhikers for practically every coral species where the pest only targets a particular coral. the pests are also all extremely hard to get rid of - so there are very strict quarantine rules for everything (that some people don't follow at all, but I'm OCD)

I'm very happy as my chaetomorpha has arrived, and is now in it's grow tank under the underwater grow light :^)
dosing with ATI nutrition C / N / P for now

small tank will be just fine with a large fan.

A big tank you can make a diy chiller with flexible tubing and a minifride.

The issue with the temperate fish is yes they can survive in warm water. But their digestive system cannot handle prolonged temperatures, As well as lower dissolved oxygen content in the water.

Personally I would suggest to aim to get the tank at LEAST below 65 degrees farenhight (i dont know that it europoor) for long term success.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4428848
Everything you listed applies to pic-related as well. They have slit pupils and large whiskers because they are naturally nocturnal animals. They have large tails because they are for warmth protection, not balance. Saying they are more 'closer' to cats than wolves are to cats are (in terms of convergence) is true, but it's a fallacy. Nobody is saying that lions are closer to wolves than African wild cats are because they are larger and live in groups, even though this is also a true statement. It's this type of comparison which I think is inane.

>>4428851
Foxes aren't solitary in the same way wild cats are. Wild cats spend practically their entire adult life alone, as nomads, and their communication with others of their species mostly being done with territory and scent marking, and their physical encounters mostly involve fighting disputes or mating. Foxes and tanuki are social animals that live in groups, and typically have an established den or living area. They also are characteristically known for their social aspect of playing with each other for fun, wagging their tails, and their high range of vocalizations (barking, howling, whining, etc) which they use to communicate with each other. Foxes are naturally possess canine-like movement and behavior due to their biology. Just look at footage like this >>4427716 and tell me you can't see the difference.

Pegion is probably sick, pigeons who know they will die become lethargic and pick a spot to die in away from the flok. Survival is slim even if you get it to the vet imo especially if it isnt eating.
If you want go to a vet pharmacy buy an antibiotic then mix the solution with bread and put it out for pigeon to eat

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4435055
Try to catch the pigeon even if it gets spooked & flies/glides to the ground.
Recommend using a larger hand towel to wrap them like a burrito.
Hard to tell it's age from pic, but if it's beak is pink/fleshy vs solid grey beak with white nostrils, it may just be a lost/dehydrated baby (pigeon parents abandon their young pretty early on)
If You have seeds, start small
For drink, assuming You have some, put some apple cider vinegar in the water.
If they're in need of a little tlc, they'll bounce back.
If not, hopefully You at least get to spend the last moments of their life showing them a lil love.
GL anon

posts.sub: Which dog breed makes for best companion?
posts.com:
I've given up on human women, the handfull relations I had I was emotionally neglected and played with. I've reached the conclusion that only in animals will I find unconditional love. I'm well set in life with a good job that I can work part time, I just want to relax, play music and enjoy the company of a dog.
So here's the catch, for most of my life living with my parents we had cats, there was one female cat that I had a really strong connection to and it to me, however it's way of showing love was mostly to lay at my feet in bed or sit next to me on the sofa with some space inbetween while watching TV and enjoying a nuzzle every now and then but not too much.
I'm living on my own and I'm looking for a dog, I've never owned one but I'm confident I'll be able to take care of it's needs including exercise.

What dog breed shows it's love in a way that matches human love the closest?
I'm talking about the following kinds of behaviour:

-Hike together through the forest, sitting down and just enjoying each other's company
-Laying against/on top of me while I'm watching TV
-Laying against me in bed
-Looking at me with adoration as I return home
-Enjoying long cuddles
-...

What I don't want:
-Excessive drooling
-Pitbulls
-Chihuahua or other breeds this small

I was thinking of a Border collie but I want to hear what you guys think or have experienced first cause I know jackshit about dogs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438432
>Where do these end up?
In other homes because people would rather pay $250 on craiglist and get a dog no strings attached than $250 at the shelter after an essay format application, background check, and a contract allowing for home visits. Some breeds are also almost certain to have 3 or 4 litters in their life because the adopt and keep rate is nearly 100% for them and if they go to shelters its not for long (like golden retrievers) and craigslist dogs are often intact.

>>4438622
Responsibly, they don't. Irresponsibly their dogs have free run of the home and yard for the day with 0 sueprvision and escapes and intrusions are frequent, hence spay and neuter.

Responsibly, if you work a true full time job (8 hours a day, often more, 5 days a week, often more, add an hour or three for a commute), you MUST have a family at home that likes taking care of the dog as well. Don't listen to crate training copers, they basically abuse animals and mistake submission and learned helplessness for "calm". Dogs sleep a ton, but need the vast majority of their waking hours filled with mental stimulation rather than a void of a dark enclosure. Just being in the same room as someone else they can conceive of socializing with can be enough for them!

Big hang up: Many, many breeds of dogs, especially the more obedient and velcro/adoring stare dogs, will not socialize with other dogs. They're together but they're all lonely and waiting for people to show up. That's why anon says get a husky, they're not like this and can keep other dogs company. Huskies have isolation, not separation, anxiety. Most dogs get separation anxiety.

3 hours and then 3 hours is fine. Large adult dogs and humans can spend up to 5 or 6 hours 100% indoors taking a nap.

If you're moving to Ontario in the Toronto area, Ottawa area, or Thunder Bay, you don't need to worry about animals much as those are large cities. Plenty of great parks to see within a reasonable drive though, especially around St. Lawrence River and Niagara Falls.

However if you are moving to a rural area on the Great Lakes you can see moose, grey wolves, black bears, coyote, etc. None of them are dangerous to humans as long as you stay at least 150 meters away from them. Don't go off trails though, it is very easy to get lost in thick woods or marshland.

Don't fuck with the Canadian geese though, they will rip your throat out.

If a deer/car collision is unavoidable, speed up and make that fucker bounce off you to reduce car damage. (NOTE: DO NOT ATTEMPT WITH MOOSE. DO NOT ATTEMPT ANYTHING WITH MOOSE. You probably won't encounter any, but be aware)

As winter sets in you might get some red and black bugs gathering on your building trying to find a warm place. They're harmless.
That endless buzzing in summer? Cicadas.
Get a metal trash can that latches shut. Raccoons will go through your trash if left outside for the week. It's rare from them to get into your garbage bags for pickup day, though.

>>4437359
I'm an Australian that lived in the great lakes area of Canada for a little while. Unfortunately it was about 15 years ago and I was a kid at the time so my memory is a little hazy but I'll give my best recollection.

Squirrels are everywhere. It's not really novel for people there but we don't really have small furry mammals running around in the daytime and I found that pretty cool. If you go to decent sized bits of woodland you can see beaver damage on the trees too.
I don't recall having any issues with Canada geese, in fact I would make a game out of seeing how close I can get without spooking them. I assume they're like magpies in Australia where there are plenty of recorded attacks but they're not anywhere close to being as aggressive or threatening as memes would suggest.
Apparently basically all their snakes are nonvenomous.
Deer are the ecological equivalent of kangaroos and (at least the smaller ones) will behave similarly ie they're not a big deal.
Summer was warmer than I expected (tops of 30ish) and uncomfortably humid. We were living quite far south though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4438268
>Apparently basically all their snakes are nonvenomous.
Our snakes, spiders and biting insects (except ticks, fleas, chiggers and skeeters) are all completely inoffensive.
Our "scariest" spider is the black widow, and it could definitely fuck you up, it's almost impossible to die from them. Plus they're very chill temper wise and just don't bother people that often.

HOWEVER
If ever you decide to go out in the woods, in particular the swamplands of eastern Ontario, you will be hounded by the largest and most aggressive mosquitos on the planet. What's different from one of your Mozzies compared to our national bird is that Canadian mosquitos have to survive winter. They have much less time during the year to be active and successfully breed, so when it's spring time, literally millions of the fuckers get active at the exact same time and they will hunt you down for fucking miles.

posts.com:
Wikipedia tells me you guys don't have rabies.
- If you see a mammal acting oddly or foaming at the mouth, STAY THE FUCK AWAY FROM IT and call it in to the police.
- If you a bitten by a wild animal and it is feasible to do so, catch it. They'll want to test it for rabies.
- Either way, go to the emergency room asap. If were unable to catch the animal, they're probably gonna want to give you rabies shots. It'll suck, but it's better than being dead.
- RABIES DOES NOT HAVE A CURE. If you reach the stage where it presents in you, you are already dead. The rabies shot is a preventative measure to stop it before it overtakes you. Do not wait to get treated.

Dogs are great, but people underestimate how much active work they take.
Do a bunch of research and make sure you 100% understand what you are taking on.

Despite popular culture and all the jokes and what not, Cats show just as much affection and give you just as much love and attention as dogs do. They are just more subtle about it, but they will bond with you and be a friend for life.

Cats are a million times easier to keep as a pet, as they are far more independent.
If you feel like a dog is far too much work after your research, go to some pounds or rescues and find a kitten or young cat that just clicks with you.

Pets can absolutely help out loneliness.

>>4400543
If you want ducks, just handcatch them. Feed them, gain their trust. Give them bread, first some floating bits, when you have them within reach, squish the bread so that it sinks.

When they start diving for it, throw a few sinking pieces, grab them when they stick their heads under.

I used to do this to stop the ducks from trying to eat my fishing bait, just hold one (male for best results-) upside down for the rest to see. Then release, no problems for the rest of the day.

Or keep them, free pets/food.

>>4400543
I’ve owned like every breed of domestic duck and also some exotic ones like mandarins and wood ducks. Never had an issue with aggression. In domestic ducks drakes will only pick on other birds because they’re trying to rape them. They’re certainly a lot more docile to each other than chickens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400543
They have random personalities and males will fight like roosters will.
We have a male that was raised with chickens and he fucking despises our chickens and will chase them. Another male call duck is tiny as hell but will try and nip at your ankles. The rest are pretty chill.
Depending on the drake you will need 2-4 hens for him. Otherwise they will literally breed the poor females to death. Although sometimes you can get away with one to one ratios.
Call ducks especially pair off well, but don't like swimming like other ducks and prefer just to splash in shallow puddles and dishes.
Our one bossy female call duck is pretty funny since she will quack very loudly if her flock gets more than a few feet from her. They will then circle back to her.
Also if they aren't making a nest ducks will lay eggs wherever they fucking want. So keep that in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4403365
Ours did pretty well nesting, but we never let them hatch since we had enough birds at the time. Only thing to keep in mind is to make sure their area is fairly good size.
When the ground is wet and muddy ducks will bury their beaks in them and look for bugs. Problem is that this will add up and soon their pen will be full of small holes everywhere. Because they are some of the largest ducks if they step in one of those holes they can hurt their legs. Ducks have very fragile legs and larger ones especially.
We have an old drake that hurt his leg and doesn't move much. Honestly surprising he has made it this long.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4438487
Owls being dumb is an idea that mostly comes from falconry. And tbqh while it's true that they're not the most intelligent birds (that goes to corvids) they're not actually that stupid. Falconers think owls are stupid because they aren't as trainable as hawks and falcons, and falconers are usually handling them during the daytime. But owls aren't trainable using conventional falconry methods because they don't respond to food in the same way that other BOP do, and of course they're lethargic and don't seem very bright during the daytime because they're nocturnal. It would be like if someone woke you up at 3 a.m. and demanded that you immediately take an IQ test. You probably wouldn't do super great. When flown at night, owls demonstrate a lot more intelligence.

tl;dr: Owls aren't stupid, they're just different from other birds of prey and that makes them seem dumb to people who are used to dealing with hawks and falcons.

No ornithischian was ever as populous as the sauropodomorphs until the mid-late Cretaceous when hadrosaur and ceratopsian biomass became the dominant presence. >>4428507

Explains why theropods got so massive and macroraptorial so quickly in the Jurassic - if the given stock of prey species was dominated by massive sauropodomorphs (which evolved to huge sizes as a defence mechanism against theropods), and the ratio of ornithopods was lower, while other ornithischians were evolving armoured defences which require greater specialisation to get through, the clearest niche to fill would be to get bigger and bigger along with the prey. The colossal carnosaurs of the Early to Mid Cretaceous - the carcharodontosaurs - were the apogee of this development, evolved to hunt the giant titanosaur species that roamed across the Southern Hemisphere during the break-up of Gondwana. Only when ornithischians eclipsed sauropods in the mid-late Cretaceous did the specialisation of the giant carnosaurs become their gradual undoing, as they were themselves outcompeted by smaller, more robust abelisaurids and tyrannosaurids, which were better adapted for hunting new ornithischian stock. And then, only when ornithischians became truly massive themselves in the Late Cretaceous (giant hadrosaurs and chasmosaurine ceratopsians), did tyrannosaurids catch up in the form of giants like Tarbosaurus and Tyrannosaurus.

>>4430395

>tyrannosaur competition causing their extinction

I misspoke, I wasn't necessarily trying to say that tyrannosaurs outcompeted carnosaurs directly, but rather than whatever bio-ecological shift that saw a change in the ratio of prey species in the Northern Hemisphere from more sauropods to more ornithischians was also what saw the decline of absolutely massive carnosaurs like the carcharodontosaurs, and opened up new niches for smaller robust theropods like abelisaurs and tyrannosaurs. Obviously it's never going to be as cut and dry as that, but we can theorise that the gradual decline of the carcharodontosaurs and their disappearance from the fossil record by the Cenomanian (when they truly reached their greatest sizes with Giganotosaurus, Mapusaurus and Carcharodontosaurus) could be connected to the shift in sauropod populations, and that shift also eventuated the success and diversity of abelisaurids and tyrannosaurids in the last 25 million years of the Cretaceous, both in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. We can perhaps theorise some large scale biogeographical shift that meant that carcharodontosaurs, which were specialised to be giant apex predators hunting the juveniles of the huge titanosaurs (or potentially forming packs and hunting adults), could no longer cope. Usually this kind of specialisation is a double edged sword - you're king of the castle while things are stable, at the highest trophic level, but when there are ecological shifts, migrations or other environmental factors, your specialisation can be a handicap. The ancestral lineages of abelisaurs and tyrannosaurs were most likely generalists, and when the Mid Cretaceous transitioned to the Late Cretaceous, it seems that they were the ones to benefit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430395
>>4430432

Again, like you said, the Cenomanian seems to exhibit shifts in the fossil record when it comes to the dominance of different large theropod lineages. The spinosaurids also thin out of the fossil record at this time, and they were clearly very specialised compared to other tetanurans.
The megaraptorans are a bit of a wild card, if they were indeed allosauroids, then they could be an argument for smaller, lightweight carnosaurs with long grasping forelimbs surviving where massive carcharodontosaurs could not.
Maybe this biogeographical transition and faunal turnover, if it did happen, could be linked to the Bonarelli anoxia event, which was related to the development of large igneous provinces across the equator due to marine transgression and the continued break up of Gondwanaland. Sea levels rose, choking littoral and delta ecosystems which supported spinosaurids, but also potentially shrinking the floodplains that the giant titanosaurs would have relied upon as nesting grounds. The carbon cycle disturbance also interrupted the marine oxygen cycle, leading to 500,000 years of decline in marine biodiversity, as reflected in the fossil record with reductions in plankton and foraminifer biodiversity. The increase in average water depth would have seawater to become less eutrophic in shallow, epicontinental seas, and this brought about the extinction of the ichthyosaurs and pliosaurs, just like you said. Then, over the following strata, mosasaurs grow to gigantic sizes and dominant the interior seaways of North America and Europe, and the epicontinental seas around Zealandia. So there was definitely a faunal turnover in the ocean, which may have had analogues on land. Something was going on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430433
>>4430395

So my argument is not that one group outcompeted the other, but rather that some ecological, biogeographical or general environmental shift meant that carcharodontosaurs couldn't keep up, and other lineages of theropods eventually, after many millions of years, grew to fill the new apex predators niches, this time hunting ceratopsians and hadrosaurs.
I think the last giant carnosaur in North America we can see in the fossil record was Acrocanthosaurus, which existed in a transitional marginal floodplain ecosystem around the rim of the growing Western Interior Seaway, and was extinct by the Cenomanian. Obviously fossilisation means we generally have a bias towards floodplain ecosystems in the Early Cretaceous (sedimentation), but clearly something was happening in the Northern Hemisphere in the time that set the scene for the larger changes by the end of the Cretaceous.
However, you're right that there are big terrestrial gaps in the Mid Cretaceous fossil record that mean that this is all purely hypothetical. A giant late-surviving carnosaur from the last 25 million years of the Cretaceous could be discovered that would throw up more questions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4437773
Generally baby birds are fumbling around everywhere and attracting people's attentions during the summer months, when they've just gotten out of the nest and learning to fly. Do you live in an area of the world that has summer in February? If it's not summer over there, fledglings should not be around yet at this time of the year.
If you do have summer right now: looking at the bird's beak would show if it's a baby or an adult. I can't get a good look at the beak from that angle, so you have to do it yourself. Google "baby bird gape flange"; baby birds like that have yellow "lips" around them while adult birds lose them.
From that picture it looks like a European siskin, or possibly some other siskin species related to it. Some South American species seem to look kinda similar, but I'm not familiar with them. Either way, siskins eat seeds.

Baby birds during nesting season are supposed to be left alone. If it's a baby and you can put it back, that's what you're supposed to do. But adult birds that can't fly are a different matter. If an adult bird can't fly, something's wrong with it.
If there is an injury, it's hard to heal such tiny and fragile birds though. The best you can do it is put it in a warm box, leave it in peace, and hope for the best. If there's any luck, it's just temporarily stunned by something and it'll recover in a couple of hours. If there's no such luck, at least it'll pass away in a comfortable place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4437821
A picture of gape flanges on a sparrow, to illustrate the difference. It's these yellow lips that can make a baby bird look permanently grumpy.
I looked up pictures of siskin fledglings. None of them look like the bird in your picture. Baby birds in general tend to have dull colors before they mature and gain more vibrant adult coloring. IMO that's an adult male in your picture, OP. If so, trying to help an adult bird that can't fly is not a bad thing.
Does the bird seem lethargic or alert? Regardless of its age, I think lethargy is always a warning sign.

At the same time, in ZT1 you can mix and match certain animals but it's tough to get the exhibit just right but it's that challenge I enjoy.
PLUS there's like 300 animals in the first one and like 40 animals in 2, so there's that.
But I WILL say this about ZT1, the dinosaurs have always been fucking glitched ever since it came out. If there is a tree in a mean dinosaur's exhibit like a t-rex, it will b-line right for that tree and immediately demolish it which turns into rubble which they don't like, so to circumvent this I've always put the necessary amount of dinosaur trees in another section of the exhibit just there because the game needs you to have trees to keep the animal happy, but I block it off with fence like a separate adjacent exhibit, except for 1 tile which I then block off with water so they can't get to the trees. Fucking ridiculous, but whatever.

>>4432332
Animals don't trample at high happiness, just make the rest of the exhibit better. T. Rexes are one of the fussiest animals in the game and basically need perfect exhibits to stay happy but it's completely possible.

>>4435761
That's why you should manually assign zoo keepers to exhibits. Unless there's an emergency they don't wander far from their assigned exhibits, if they only have one more often than not they just get in this loop of walking in and out the door until they find something to do, and most zoo keepers can handle 3-4 normal size exhibits by themselves if they're next to each other, though bigger exhibits should have dedicated or multiple zoo keepers. Still a good idea to have a few unassigned zoo keepers floating around wherever to drop into exhibits that need extra help like if the lion exhibit gets covered in crap. Scientists are slow as fuck and Divers have really, really bad pathfinding in tanks so it's good idea to have those dedicated to a single exhibit though.

>>4432332
The trick is to make the exhibit better before they hatch. From what I can remember, you can still check their thoughts on the exhibit while they're still an egg.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4437522
You can check the egg's status, but all it will say is that the egg requires the care of a scientist, but generally speaking it is a good idea to make an approximation of what will make the dinosaur happy before you let it hatch. You can use the in-game awards to gauge when you've designed an exhibit sufficiently, but that will only work a certain number of times depending on what awards you're getting. If you're that autistic about it, you can just go to a guide website like Wisco's and pre-build the entire thing before you even place the egg in exactly to that animal's specifications.

>>4428063
>homeless while you work
Volunteer positions at stables are usually done on the weekend because stable hands/managers want to get their work done early, and they're not going to trust you enough to give you work that'll last the entire day. Most likely they'll ask you to muck out one or two stalls and fill up some water buckets. This is pretty light work done on days you'll be free on, you should be finished in about 2-3 hours even if you don't have experience cleaning stalls. Mind you that you won't be leading around horses or anything at the start because of the liability issues.

But sometimes, humpback whale bulls fight so unless I have footage to disprove it, I'll assume blue whale bulls fight with massive fluke slaps or ramming the opponent by lifting themselves out of the water and dropping onto them.
Head ramming is, by the way, not possible for them because their jaws are so fragile. Blue whales also have an organ between the tips of their lower jaws that helps them determine a bait ball density and if it's even worth opening their gigantic maws for it. They use up a lot of energy to fill their mouths and press out the water. If the bait ball is not big enough to over compensate that energy loss, the whale won't even bother with it.
